bibl.title: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, April 5, 1923

div1.p: Barber requests information about the prevalence of different malaria parasites in relation to the season in the southern United States.

div1.head: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, April 5, 1923
div1.opener:
N. M. C
Barber
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Box. 231, Crowley, La. Apr. 5, 1923.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Could you tell me off hand if any one has published
figures showing the incidence of different types of malaria parasites
by months in the Southern U.S.? In my goings-over of the literature I find
some more or less definite statements as to the prevalence of estivo-autumnal in
the fall and the like, but I find thus far no collections of figures by
the month. I presume the dominance of different types will
follow about the same curves as those found in the temperate or subtropical
countries of Europe-I have a good set of figures from Georgia examinations
and one from Alabama which indicate this, but it would be worth while to
get the facts clearly/ and from a lot of figures. So if no one else has done it
already I am going to collect some figures and see what they look like, and have
already prepared a tentative blank. If it is true as Wenyon states, that
summer and fall cases of estivo-autumnal are presumably new cases, these should be
proportionately fewer after extensive antimalaria operations or after a severe
drought. It may be of interest to see how these proportions come out.
Any suggestions you may make without going to any more trouble than
would be involved in a short letter would be very welcome.
div1.closer: Respectfully M.A. Barber. Special Expert. Answered- April 15/23
